docs.lead_paragraph: Long Island First Frank Tracy Jr.'s motive was simple. He wanted Long Islanders to know that they lived in a special place. ''Frank had this vision that we needed an organization that would raise awareness about all the riches we have on Long Island,'' said Brian R. McCaffrey, president of Promote Long Island, the not-for-profit organization that Mr. Tracy founded a decade ago.

headline.main: In Lieu of Flowers: Remembering 17 Who Made a Difference

docs.abstract: Year-end profiles of notable Long Islanders who died in 2003: Promote Long Island founder Frank Tracy Jr; Nassau County Police Comr William Willett; Oyster Bay historian Dorothy Horton McGee; Paris Review editor George Plimpton; Bay Street Theater benefactor and board member Elaine Steinbeck; stained-glass artist Paul Wood; Suffolk Sports Hall of Fame co-founder and president Arthur Figliozzi; former Stony Brook University Hospital director and chief executive Michael Maffetone; Hofstra University trustee and board chairman Allan Tod Gittleson; breast cancer activist Diane Sackett Nannery; former Rockville Centre Mayor William Harry Lister; former Adelphi University president Timothy W Costello; Ed Buscemi, known as Mr Long Beach; Amalgamated Transit Union Local 1061 leader William H Harrison; philanthropist John Funk; former United Cerebral Palsy of Greater Suffolk executive director Kathleen O'Callaghan Maul; Stony Brook University African Studies chairman William McAdoo; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''HAVE a wonderful flight and may the wind be at your back and paradise be all you hoped. Aloha.'' Waiting for my connecting flight to Kauai in the Honolulu airport, I reread this e-mail message from DJ Colbert, owner of Emma's Cottage, with a bit of trepidation. I had arranged to rent her cottage in Kilauea, on Kauai's exclusive North Shore, for $500 for five days. The area has only a few rather expensive resorts and hotels, so I'd almost given up hope of staying there, until I found my way to the bustling online marketplace of North Kauai private cottage rentals.

headline.main: A Cottage Of One's Own in Kauai

docs.abstract: Daisann McLane Frugal Traveler article on visit to Kauai, Hawaii, and stay at rental cottage in Kilauea on island's exclusive North Shore; photos; map (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER federal agents raided 60 Wal-Mart stores in October and found more than 200 illegal immigrants in the cleaning crews, the world's largest retailer was quick to defend itself from this enormous embarrassment. Wal-Mart's officers said they had no idea those workers were illegal, insisting they knew next to nothing about the workers from Mexico, Mongolia, Russia and elsewhere because they were employed by contractors. Nor did Wal-Mart know, its spokesmen said, that the contractors were cutting corners by not paying overtime or Social Security taxes or by flouting other labor laws, as the investigators claimed. Like Wal-Mart, thousands of American enterprises rely on labor contractors to help hold down costs, and those industries -- from New York apparel makers to California's vegetable growers -- have given similar ''I had no idea'' responses when their contractors have been accused of cutting corners.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Middlemen in the Low-Wage Economy

docs.abstract: Thousands of American enterprises rely on labor contractors to help hold down costs, and they claim they are unaware when contractors are found to cut corners by employing illegal aliens, not paying overtime or Social Security taxes or by flouting other labor laws; critics of business-contractor ties insist that companies know exactly what they are getting when they hire outsiders to supply them with labor; now American companies are facing increasing legal challenges to hold them accountable for their contractors' practices; recent case against Wal-Mart cited; photo (M)

As some people put it, ''What goes around comes around.'' But let Norma Tavis of Vancouver, Wash., tell her own story.

docs.lead_paragraph: The recent implosion of some of Governor McGreevey's biggest initiatives led to rampant sneering that the governor lacked the ability to get anything done. So it seems only fair to point out that since Mr. McGreevey took office 23 months ago, no one else on Trenton has done much of anything either. The 210th legislature is preparing to fold, having used its last few voting sessions to designate the highbush blueberry the state fruit and the years 2002 to 2011 the National Bone and Joint Decade. What legislators did not do, and will not do in the last few sessions, is enact legislation addressing any of New Jersey's abiding, agreed-upon, even distressing problems: property taxes, education financing, sprawl, auto pollution, a depleted Transportation Trust Fund and a campaign finance system that promotes influence-peddling.

headline.main: Meaningful Legislation? Don't Hold Your Breath

docs.abstract: Laura Mansnerus On Politics column on lackluster performance of New Jersey legislature in 23 months since Gov James McGreevey took office; holds failure to act on some of state's most pressing problems cannot be blamed on Senate's 20-20 political split (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration is proposing a new policy that would punish hospitals, drugstores and other health care providers that charge Medicare or Medicaid substantially more than their usual charges to private insurers. Violators could be excluded from participation in any federal health care program, a severe penalty that is being bitterly fought by the health care industry.

headline.main: Some Health Care Providers May Face Payment Penalty

docs.lead_paragraph: MERCK & COMPANY has long been the crown jewel of New Jersey's rich pharmaceutical industry. The company was the first to commercialize penicillin in the 1940's. In 1987, it introduced the breakthrough cholesterol drug Mevacor. A pioneer in H.I.V.-AIDS treatments, the company is working on a promising vaccine to stop the killer that is ravaging Africa. Yet despite its proud past, Merck, the world's third-largest drug company, which has its headquarters in Whitehouse Station, now faces its own ills.

headline.main: Hard Times In Star Part Of the State Economy

docs.abstract: Article on challenges facing New Jersey's pharmaceutical industry; Merck & Co of Whitehouse Station, world's third-largest drug company, is about to lose patent protection for its top-selling cholesterol drug, Zocor, has failed to develop blockbuster new drugs and has canceled two drugs for depression and diabetes that were in late-stage development; Kenilworth-based Schering-Plough is cutting labor costs through layoffs and early retirement; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN lieu of flowers, many obituary notices say, ''the family requests ...'' What follows may be a suggestion for a donation to a cause supported by the person who died: a college scholarship fund, a soup kitchen, a symphony, a shelter for abandoned pets. Or perhaps the family wants to direct contributions to an organization seeking a cure for a disease. Then again, the money could go toward a more tangible monument: the planting of trees, land preserved for a park, a stained-glass window in a house of worship.

headline.main: Legacies of Notable Lives; From Politicians to Teachers to Dedicated Members of a Community

docs.lead_paragraph: Island's Somber Past Q. When my uncle, an architect, died, among his effects I found pictures labeled ''North Brother Island Project -- April 5, 1946.'' The pictures appear to be of nice Art Deco hospital buildings. What are they and what happened to them? A. North Brother Island, off Hunts Point in the Bronx, is probably best remembered as the place where the steamer General Slocum ran aground while burning on July 15, 1904. It has also been site of several public institutions, chosen for its comparative remoteness. The most famous was the Riverside Hospital, opened in 1885 to care for victims of infectious diseases like typhus, cholera and smallpox. The hospital, which expanded haphazardly as need arose, was a dumping ground for the destitute sick, most of them immigrants, as in the tuberculosis epidemic of 1903 and the polio epidemic of 1916.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pei Li Tsang sipped from a cup of tea as she sat on a couch in her Sheepshead Bay apartment. Her shy daughter, Anny, 10, a professed bookworm, read a Harry Potter novel while her brother, Jason, 7, laughed at a car chase on television. It was a good moment. Peaceful. Satisfying. They had left China to come to America for moments just like this one.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; As Chinese Immigrants Struggle in a Strange Land, Just Asking for Help Is a Challenge
